Thus have I heard: Once, the Buddha was staying in the country of Shravasti. To the east of the city, there was a woman
whose son was named Vyaghra, and people called her the mother of Vyaghra. The Buddha was sitting in the hall of the mother of Vyaghra.

There was a woman who upheld the precepts, named DÄsaka, who on the fifteenth day of the month, got up in the morning to bathe, and had her seven daughters-in-law also bathe and put on nice clothes. Before noon, they had a meal. After the meal, they washed their hands and brought the seven daughters-in-law to where the Buddha was. They bowed to the Buddha.
The Buddha said:
Take your seats.
They all stepped back and sat down.
The Buddha asked UpÄli DÄsaka:
Why are you bathing and wearing nice clothes today, and coming to the Buddha with your daughters-in-law?
DÄsaka said:
Today is the fifteenth day, I am fasting. I heard that one should fast six times a month. I am fasting together with my daughter-in-law, not daring to be negligent.
The Buddha told Dushala:

The Buddha's correct fasting method has eight precepts, enabling people to transcend the world and no longer fall into the three evil realms. Wherever they are born, they will always have blessings and virtues. They will also attain Buddhahood based on the fundamental causes and conditions of the eight precepts.
What is the Buddha's correct fasting method?

Here, virtuous people uphold the precepts and fast on the six days of each month. They fast on the eighth day of the month, the fourteenth day, the fifteenth day, the twenty-third day, the twenty-ninth day, and the thirtieth day.
On fasting days, they get up in the morning and tell the family members:

'Today, my body is fasting. In the household, for this one day, do not drink alcohol, do not quarrel, do not talk about money and wealth. The matters and thoughts in the mind and words spoken in the household should be like an arhat.

' An arhat has no intention to kill. On fasting days, one should also uphold the precepts like an arhat, with no intention to kill, no intention to beat, thinking of animals and insects, allowing them to always live, like the intention of an arhat. This is the first precept.
Today and throughout the night, uphold the intention not to kill, not allowing killing. Uphold the intention like this, for the Buddha's one precept.
The Buddha said:
On fasting days, one should uphold the intention like an arhat, with no greedy mind, no longing for anything in the world, no intention of greed for even a hair or vegetable.

On fasting days, uphold the intention like this, like an arhat. Those who are wealthy should think of giving, while those who are poor and have nothing should always think of giving. This is the second precept.
The Buddha said:
On the fast day, one should hold one's thoughts as if one were an arhat. Arhats do not keep wives nor think of wives, nor do they crave women nor have lustful thoughts.
On the fast day, holding one's thoughts like this as if one were an arhat, this is the third precept.
The Buddha said:

On the fast day, one should hold one's thoughts as if one were an arhat. Do not speak falsely or hurt others' feelings. When speaking, immediately recite the Buddha's sutras. When not speaking, just think of all that is good.
On the fast day, holding one's thoughts like this as if one were an arhat, this is the fourth precept.
The Buddha said:
On the fast day, one should hold one's thoughts as if one were an arhat. Arhats do not drink alcohol, do not think of alcohol, do not contemplate alcohol, and consider alcohol to be evil.
On the fast day, holding one's thoughts like this as if one were an arhat, this is the fifth precept.
The Buddha said:

On the fast day, one should hold one's thoughts as an arhat would. An arhat's thoughts are not on singing and dancing, and even if he hears it, he is not delighted. He does not think of the fragrance of flowers.
On the fast day, holding one's thoughts like an arhat is the sixth precept.
The Buddha said:
On the fast day, one should hold one's thoughts as an arhat would. An arhat does not sleep on high and luxurious beds, and does not think of sleeping on high and luxurious beds.
On the fast day, holding one's thoughts like an arhat is the seventh precept.
The Buddha said:
On the fast day, one should hold one's thoughts as an arhat would. An arhat eats at noon, and after noon until dawn, he does not eat again, but may drink honeyed beverages.
On the fast day, holding one's thoughts like an arhat is the eighth precept.
The Buddha further told UpÄli:
Here, there are people whose hair is dirty. They wash their hair themselves, and after washing, they rejoice and say:
'The dirt on my head has been removed.'
Those who observe the eight precepts for a day and a night rejoice the next day. They think:
'The Buddha's sutras and precepts are like this.'
The evil intentions in their minds are removed, and the good intentions return.
The Buddha said:
There are people whose bodies are covered with dirt. They enter the water to wash, and all the dirt on their bodies is removed.
When they come out of the water, they rejoice and say:
'My dirt is gone and my body feels light.'
Those who observe the precepts for a day and a night rejoice the next day, thinking of the Buddha's right words, and think to themselves:
'When will I attain the Way, so that my mind no longer moves or runs, so that my mind is one, and my will is set on the Way of non-action?' The Buddha said:
There is a person whose clothes are very dirty, but they can be washed with ash to remove the dirt, and the person is then delighted.
If a person observes the precepts for one day and one night, they will be joyful the next day, and will think of the monks, saying:
'Among the monks, there are stream-enterers, once-returners, non-returners, and arhats.'
They think of the monks like this.
The Buddha said:
It is like a person having a mirror, but the mirror is dirty. If they polish away the dirt, the mirror will become clear.
If a person observes the precepts for one day and one night, has a compassionate mind towards the world, and their mind opens up like a clear mirror, they should not have any thoughts of anger.

If a person observes the precepts for one day and one night, pities the world, purifies their mind, reflects on their own thoughts, and contemplates the impurities in their own body like this, they should not become angry again.

The Buddha told Sudatta:
People in the world have many worries about family affairs. For this reason, I allow them to fast and observe the eight precepts once a month.

If there are virtuous people who wish to quickly attain the stage of arhatship, or quickly attain Buddhahood, or be reborn in the heavens, and can focus their minds and unify their thoughts, fasting on the fifteenth day of the month is also good, fasting on the twentieth day is also good;
But people have many worries about family affairs, so I allow fasting once a month on the six designated days.
Fasting on the six designated days is like the ocean, which cannot be measured with a bushel. The blessings of fasting for one day and one night cannot be calculated.
The Buddha told Sudatta:
Take your son and daughter-in-law back and recite this method of correct fasting, the eight precepts.
Sudatta, the head of the clan, bowed to the Buddha and left.
